TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit BehaviorService extends System.Object implements class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: Manages user interface in the designer. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> is created, it adds a transparent window over the designer frame. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> can then use this window to render user interface elements, called <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph> objects, as well as catch all mouse messages. In this way, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> can control designer behavior.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> class supports a behavior stack, onto which <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> objects can be pushed. When a message is intercepted through the transparent window, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> can send the message to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> at the top of the stack. This enables different user interface modes depending on the currently pushed <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior>. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> is used to render all <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph> objects, such as selection borders, sizing handles, and smart tags. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> also controls many design-time behaviors, such as using snaplines, dragging, and selecting.
For more information, see [Behavior Service Overview](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/7c60cc41-4324-46b5-b444-b39eda7cb33f).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to create your own <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> based class that responds to user clicks.
[!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService/cpp/Form1.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService/CS/Form1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService/VB/Form1.vb#1)]

## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to add <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Adorner> objects to and remove them from a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorServiceAdornerCollection>. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> class.

Docs.summary: Occurs when the starts a drag-and-drop operation.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> raises the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.BeginDrag> event immediately before it starts a drag-and-drop operation.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance valuetype System.Drawing.Rectangle ControlRectInAdornerWindow(class System.Windows.Forms.Control c) cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns the bounding of a .
Docs.returns: The bounding of a translated to the adorner window coordinates.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The adorner window is a transparent window that resides on top of the designer's frame. This window is used by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> to intercept all messages. It also serves as a unified canvas on which to paint a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph>.

Docs.summary: Returns the location of a translated to adorner window coordinates.
Docs.returns: A value indicating the location of in adorner window coordinates.

remarks.format:

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Dispose() cil managed

Docs.summary: Releases all resources used by the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Call <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.Dispose%2A> when you are finished using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.Dispose%2A> method leaves the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> in an unusable state. After calling <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.Dispose%2A>, you must release all references to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> was occupying. For more information, see [Cleaning Up Unmanaged Resources](~/docs/standard/garbage-collection/unmanaged.md) and [Implementing a Dispose Method](~/docs/standard/garbage-collection/implementing-dispose.md).
> [!NOTE] > Always call <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.Dispose%2A> before you release your last reference to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>. Otherwise, the resources it is using will not be freed until the garbage collector calls the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> object's `Finalize` method.

Docs.summary: Occurs when the completes a drag operation.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> raises the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.EndDrag> event immediately after the drag operation is complete.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).

remarks.format: ## Remarks Calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.Invalidate%2A> method forces a refresh of all <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Adorner> objects and, in turn, all <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph> objects.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Removes the current <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> from the behavior stack internally maintained by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void PushBehavior(class System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior behavior) cil managed

Docs.summary: Pushes a onto the behavior stack.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.PushBehavior%2A> method is often performed by means of a hit-tested <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void PushCaptureBehavior(class System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior behavior) cil managed

Docs.summary: Pushes a onto the behavior stack and assigns mouse capture to the behavior.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Pushing a capture behavior is often done through a hit-tested <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph>. If a behavior calls the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.PushCaptureBehavior%2A> method and mouse capture is lost, the behavior's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior.OnLoseCapture%2A> method is called.
